author: Udhav Naig
text:
With Uber slashing its prices to Rs. 6 from Rs. 8 per kiliometre for a ride in a hatchback and to Rs. 7 from Rs. 9 per kilometre for a ride in a sedan, the cab business in the city seems to have entered an exciting phase. This has prompted Ola, its competitor, to slash its fares to Rs 6 per kilometre but for its ‘Share’ services. Customers are happy with the drop in prices.

An official from Ola said, “Over the past year, we have seen a significant increase in demand that is driving increased utilisation for driver partners in the city. We are able to pass on the benefits of these efficiencies to customers in the form of fares that are as low as Rs. 6/km with Ola Share.” However, the competition between the two cab services has put drivers in a spot. Drivers say they don’t do trips for the money anymore but for the incentive that they receive for completing a set number of trips during the day. While the number of trips varies according to the company, drivers say they need to work for as many as 12 hours to bag this incentive.

The work load is a problem, says a driver.

“We are under pressure to complete these trips since we can make ends meet only if we get this incentive,” a driver said.

title: Price war between cab majors a boon for users
